data.meta_description: Schmidt, Erin , Nina Williams, and Rani T Alexander. 2014 Cultural Resource Support for Archaeological Survey at White Sands National Monument. CESU Project # NMSUDS-50, New Mexico State University and White Sands National Monument. NMCRIS Activity #
data.text:
Museum of New Mexico MNM Project: no. 65.28. Full title: An archaeological clearance investigation : an archaeological clearance survey for New Mexico State Highway Department project F-033-1(14), near San Ysidro, Sandoval County, New Mexico / prepared by William K. Boyer and Denise Fallon. Abstract: An archaeological clearance survey of LA 12533 is a multiroom pueblo of the late Pueblo III (Santa Fe) period. Archaeological surveying Pueblos Pueblo III period Sandoval County (N.M.) San Ysidro (N.M.) LA 12533

This report documents the results of archeological survey of Lake Lucero Site (LA 21162) and Huntingtin Pueblo (LA 14820) located at White Sands National Monument (WSNM or Monument) and also on White Sands Missile Range (WSMR). The two sites belong among the largest prehistoric loci at Monument (WSNM). Previous documentations revealed significant cultural resources at both sites including the remnants of pit structures and possible jacal structures as well as a variety of thermal features and substantial prehistoric trash deposits (middens).Fieldwork was performed between May 15th and June 28th, 2018. The survey of the two sites revealed the presence of vast cultural resources that have provided a massive amount datasets. These data were utilized during various specialized analyses that altogether elevate our understanding of the sitesâ€™ significance in the local and regional context.

Museum of New Mexico Project ; no. 76.06. New Mexico State Highway Department [sponsoring body] Tucumcari Survey Project Tucumcari By-Pass Project Project I-040-6(7)333 Project I-040-6(31)335 Four prehistoric lithic sites and two late nineteenth- to early twentieth-century homesteads were surveyed. A cultural resource clearance investigation was conducted to evaluate six archaeological sites, four prehistoric lithic sites and two late 19th-early 20th century homesteads. Included in this report are site summaries. Marsha Jackson prepared the section on the territorial period (1848-1912) homesteads (LA 16648, LA 16650). Research design report. Sites to be directly impacted include LA 16126, a multicomponent Archaic-Pueblo III artifact scatter; and, LA 16136, an early to mid-twentieth century Navajo structure. Three (3) sites subject to indirect impact are LA 16127, a possible Navajo burial; LA 16128, a 1920-1950 Navajo habitation; and LA 10822, a small Pueblo II pueblo. Red Mesa Survey Project Museum of New Mexico MNM Project ; no. 41.340 ; 4100340 Archeological survey of the 1-40 right-of-way and New Mexico State Highway Borrow Pits between Ciniza and Thoreau, New Mexico, revealed 24 sites, four of which have been previously recorded. A testing program to determine the nature of 11 threatened sites is presented. Recommendations made for excavation. Museum of New Mexico Project ; no 4.1 .401. State Road 264 Project Recording and archaeological testing of three sites was conducted along the State Road 264 right-of-way in McKinley County. The two sites recorded and tested include a multicomponent, prehistoric limited activity site (LA 57411) and the remains of the Wildcat Springs Trading Post, occupied sometime between 1940 and 1960. The third site (LA 59497) is a prehistoric rubble mound and midden. A portion of the midden is located within the right-of-way. The site was sketch mapped and recorded; no testing was conducted. A data recovery plan for each site is included with this report. LA 55647 LA 57411 LA 59497

A modern Navajo site and one multicomponent Navajo and Puebloan site were located in the right-of-way. The first site may have been a tent camp, and the other a Navajo herman's camp. Clearance recommended. Museum of New Mexico MNM Project ; no. 65.51.
